channel.title: Public volatile...?
channel.description: ok, i have a java file called XVector, and in it i put [code] volatile Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException { return clone(); } [/code] it is at the very end before the lcosing } of the file, and it just wont work, itused to work before but i did somehting and now it just ownt, heres the error.... [code] XVector.java:54: modifier volatile not allowed here volatile Object clone() [/code] ne clues?

well idk but it used to work, i just added some more code to the file and it stopped working…by working i never really understood what it was suposed to do but it didn’t return errors before, now it does, so i jsut removed it, because the code still seems to work fine

Read full topic

item.title: Public volatile...?
item.dc:creator: @Hiaburi Hiaburi
item.description:
@Hiaburi wrote:

yea i just ended up removing it, i wasnt sure what it was for but i saw it being used before, so i added it… i just dont get why it worked fine for awhile then caused an error out of the blue

Read full topic

item.title: Public volatile...?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Well, volatile fields are basically an alternative to using synchronization when writing concurrent programs.

If you aren’t using a program that has several threads potentially accessing the field simultaneously then you don’t need the field to be volatile.

Read full topic

item.title: Public volatile...?
item.dc:creator: @Hiaburi Hiaburi
item.description:
@Hiaburi wrote:

ok, i have a java file called XVector, and in it i put

    volatile Object clone()
        throws CloneNotSupportedException
    {
        return clone();
    }

it is at the very end before the lcosing } of the file, and it just wont work, itused to work before but i did somehting and now it just ownt, heres the error…

XVector.java:54: modifier volatile not allowed here
    volatile Object clone()

ne clues?

Read full topic
